slides.title: Welcome to Cybersecurity
slides.content:
# Introduction to Cybersecurity

Welcome to **Cybersecurity** - protecting digital systems!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Security Principles** - CIA triad
- **Cryptography** - Encryption basics
- **Threats** - Types of attacks
- **Defenses** - Protection methods

> **Fun Fact:** Cybercrime costs the world over $6 trillion annually!

slides.title: Security Principles
slides.content:
# Security Principles

## CIA Triad:

| Principle | Meaning |
|-----------|--------|
| Confidentiality | Only authorized access |
| Integrity | Data is accurate, unchanged |
| Availability | System accessible when needed |

## Additional Principles:

| Principle | Meaning |
|-----------|--------|
| Authentication | Verify identity |
| Authorization | Verify permissions |
| Non-repudiation | Cannot deny actions |

## Defense in Depth:
- Multiple layers of security
- If one fails, others protect

## Least Privilege:
- Minimum necessary permissions
- Limit damage from breaches

slides.title: Cryptography
slides.content:
# Cryptography

## Symmetric Encryption:
- Same key for encrypt/decrypt
- Fast
- Key distribution problem
- Example: AES

## Asymmetric Encryption:
- Public key and private key
- Public encrypts, private decrypts
- Slower but solves key distribution
- Example: RSA

## Hashing:
- One-way function
- Fixed-size output
- Used for passwords, integrity
- Examples: SHA-256, MD5 (outdated)

## Digital Signatures:
- Verify sender identity
- Ensure data integrity
- Private key signs, public verifies

## TLS/SSL:
- Secure communication
- Used for HTTPS
- Combines symmetric and asymmetric

slides.title: Threats and Attacks
slides.content:
# Threats and Attacks

## Malware Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|------------|
| Virus | Attaches to programs |
| Worm | Self-replicating |
| Trojan | Disguised as legitimate |
| Ransomware | Encrypts files for ransom |
| Spyware | Monitors activity |

## Attack Types:

| Attack | Method |
|--------|--------|
| Phishing | Fake emails/sites |
| SQL Injection | Malicious database queries |
| DDoS | Overwhelm with traffic |
| Man-in-the-Middle | Intercept communications |
| Social Engineering | Manipulate people |

## Vulnerabilities:
- Buffer overflow
- Cross-site scripting (XSS)
- Unpatched software
- Weak passwords

slides.title: Defenses
slides.content:
# Security Defenses

## Technical Controls:

| Defense | Protection |
|---------|------------|
| Firewall | Filter network traffic |
| Antivirus | Detect malware |
| IDS/IPS | Detect/prevent intrusions |
| VPN | Encrypt network traffic |
| MFA | Multiple authentication factors |

## Authentication Factors:
1. Something you know (password)
2. Something you have (phone, token)
3. Something you are (biometrics)

## Best Practices:
- Strong, unique passwords
- Regular updates/patches
- Backups
- Security awareness training

## Incident Response:
1. Preparation
2. Detection
3. Containment
4. Eradication
5. Recovery
6. Lessons learned

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Cybersecurity Summary

## CIA Triad:
- Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability

## Cryptography:
| Type | Key(s) |
|------|--------|
| Symmetric | Same key both ways |
| Asymmetric | Public/Private pair |
| Hashing | One-way |

## Common Threats:
- Phishing, malware, DDoS
- Social engineering

## Defenses:
- Firewalls, antivirus, MFA
- Patches, backups, training

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Cybersecurity!
